grill here. unless you guys have a relationship built on blunt communication, then you don't TELL her shit. unfortunately the best route is a subtle one involving mind games.

all girls are self-conscious to some extent, your gf is no exception. that said, you can't just call her out on her weight gain because she will either break down or be furious. you need to gently chip away at her self-esteem without being obvious and make it seem like it's coming from a good place. for example, pull up an outfit from torrid (fat bitch store) and tell her it would look cute on her frame. this will seem benign from your end but will plant a seed of self-doubt on her end. other options are to comment on thin celebrity crushes in passing, suggest you both clear out "clothes you can't wear anymore" from your closets, and/or start to walk several paces in front of her when in public. when she struggles to catch up and bitches that you're leaving her behind, nonchalantly claim that you didn't notice; your legs are just longer. she will subconsciously think you're embarrassed to be seen with her. that last one really only works if you're taller than her (and if you're not, then wtf are you complaining about you disgusting manlet lol).

another route that would require far more effort on your part would be to adopt a new diet and/or fitness routine and engross yourself in it, being sure to talk about it all the time. she will naturally feel shitty while you're jogging/lifting weights/eating spinach while she's sitting on the couch inhaling doritos. if this for some reason DOESN'T conjure shame and subsequently spur her fat ass into action, then just dump her because that's a bad deal all around.

I loved mopeds and that community a lot, more than a lot of people know and ever will know. Mopeds literally changed my life, and I had finally found something that I could do, confide in, and enjoy. I was tossed head first into that community, and I thought it was going to be a one-time thing and I'd be like "That was cool" and move on. When I realized there was people who had the same interests and common ground.

This isn't really about mopeds, it's kind of something I've always had to deal with, being the bad guy when I'm not, or I'm made out to be the bad guy and end up being a pariah all the time when I usually do nothing wrong and someone has to be a dick, start something,say or do something to make me look bad.

He said "damaged people" when I got into mopeds, I kind of saw that, people were either social butterflies or just wanted to stand around and sneer at people, hang around their own, and/or make comments. I noticed it with some people I knew too, like "They're cool, but they seem to have demons like I do". I guess that's why I fell in love with it, I was fresh out of high school, had to deal with bullying, social isolation and outcasting, I went through a lot, and when I got around a community of people with the same interests and all these things going on I found what I had been looking for and what I wanted when I was in that room behind a computer screen. I got out of my room, the city, got to be around people, got to make friends, got to experience new things, it was a really positive thing for me and I wanted to keep with it because of that.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Man, I could write a book about this but I'll give an overview.

0) The ultimate goal is to to be at peace with yourself and be able to love yourself. I know that sounds corny but you can get there.

1) Get your sleep and water intake in order. Sleep and exercise (more on that later) are medicine. Sleep determines your hormonal regulation. Bad sleep -> bad hormone profile -> bad mood -> bad attitude -> bad life choices, etc., etc.. Water is also massively important. I recommend at least 100 ounces of water a day for an adult male. 125-ish if you exercise (which you will).

2) Nutrition. 100 grams of protein, 40 grams of fat are the minimums (for a male). Calculate your TDEE (google TDEE calculator). If trying to maintain weight, eat that number. If trying to lose weight, eat 500 calories a day less.Weight yourself each morning after you use the bathroom but before drinking/eating. Track it. If the scale isn't moving in the direction you want, check your eating habits and be honest with yourself.

3) Exercise. Helps with hormones, confidence, energy. I recommend walking every day. 30 to 60 minutes. If that sounds boring, walk with a friend, listen to an audio book, whatever. It's good to be out in nature. Resistance train 2-3 times a week to start. Visit /fit/ and learn how to bench, squat, and deadlift. Be careful and take it slowly. Progress when you're co

The above three points will fix maybe 80% of your life if you actually follow them. Your body is the vehicle you move through life with. Take care of it and it will take care of you. You will find that you will have new fonts of energy, motivation, confidence, and most importantly, peace.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28008041
Continued.

4) Looksmax: Most of it is covered in the above post, honestly. Take care of your body, drop to a healthy body fat % and you're on your way. There is a man hiding under all that fat and he wants to break free. Get a decent hair cut once a month. Learn how to dress. Don't overthink it.

5) Finances: Look at your credit/debit cards or grocery bills weekly and go through your activity. With honesty, use a pen to mark what you don't need. NEED is an important word here. Netflix? Out. Candy, junk food, fast food? Out. Video games? Out. Be as severe as you can afford to be in this respect but don't make yourself miserable. If you need to play games while you cut back on other things, then fine. Just make sure you don't use it as a crutch for the rest of your life. Porn needs to go as well. Completely. Do some reading on supernormal stimuli.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28008041
>>28008062
Continued.

6) Social skills. Like all things, you can only get better at this with practice. Talk to strangers! Expect nothing, ask them about themselves. If it goes south, oh well. Shrug it off and keep trucking. They'll forget about the interaction sooner than later. I'm actually writing a long post tomorrow about an experiment I'm running about this. Keep your eyes peeled.

7) Discipline. Everything in these posts relate to depending or building discipline in some way. You need to build trust with yourself. Look at something in your room that you want to interact with (phone, video games, whatever) and stop. Tell yourself you won't touch it right now - but in five minutes. Then in five minutes, do so. Do that again with something else, ten minutes this time. Etc. What is happening is that you are making micro-promises with yourself and you're fulfilling them. It sounds silly but with enough self trust, you can build a daily walking schedule, a three-a-week lifting schedule, a study schedule. What have you. You can also use this to ween yourself of bad habits. 'I won't use porn now. I'll use it in 10 minutes' turns into 'I won't use porn today because I said I would only use it every other day/once a week/once a month/never.'

I need to do errands but some quick notes -

Read Meditations by Marcus Aurelius and Atomic Habits by James Clear. Read them until you have them basically memorized. I am 100% serious that if you read, understand, and implement the teachings in those books, your life will change for the better.

Leave your phone in a room that you do not constantly frequent. Disable all unnecessary notifications. Only check it every 30 or 60 minutes. Do allow your phone in your bedroom - it will mess with your night time habits and make it harder for you to fall asleep. Buy an old fashion alarm if you need to have one.

No TV/electronics the hour before bedtime. Again, messes with your sleep. Spend this time thinking, reading, writing, journaling, meditating, or praying.

Source: Me. I was in largely the same position as OP when I was 24. I'm 30 now. Lost 100 pounds, making 6 figures, big into physical and mental health, dating became a non-issue. Lifting, reading, writing, walking, cooking, largely at peace with myself and the universe.

posts.sub: How do I deal with loneliness and isolation?
posts.com:
It's a long story explaining the events that led to my current situation so I apologise in advance to those who could be bothered to read this.

I was supposed to be on a year abroad as part of a university exchange programme on my course, but roughly 4 months back, about two weeks before I was due to fly off I got caught up in a serious accident that could have killed me. Ended up breaking some bones and I had to withdraw from that year abroad and take a year out from university, meaning I graduate a year later than I should have.

Anyway I've been stuck at home and I'm finally better and can walk, not 100%what I was at before but I'm going to physiotherapy and can get around now. Problem is that I feel completely alone and I'm stuck at home. I can't exactly go out where I want, I've got no car and even if I did where the hell am I supposed to go?

My brother lives and works in another city so I don't see him and my parents are so busy that I hardly see them even when we live under the same roof, feels like there's nobody here but me sometimes. I got to see some school friends for a bit but they'll be going back to other cities/countries when university starts up again. Sometimes I go down to see my university friends but even that is only occasional since I live in Scotland and they're down in London so it's very expensive to travel there and I can only come down for a few days every few months or so.

It wasn't so bad at first but now I'm struggling to deal with it all. I feel so alone and I try to keep myself busy to get my mind off it but there's only so much I feel I can do here? Maybe I'm only here to vent like some idiot but is there anyway I can actually sort this shit feeling out? Sounds dumb but I crave human interaction and company, I'm so starved for it that when I get the opportunity to go out now I'm talking to random strangers as if they're good friends. It's miserable living how I do right now but I don't even know what to do to change it.

Therapy can be hit or miss. Shop around, and come to them with a concrete problem to fix. Ask for specific terms you can then look up techniques for, and bring your own research back to the therapist for input. Say you want practical techniques to use. Not all of them will provide that. Seriously.

I'll tell you straight up, I've been going to therapy on and off for decades, and it mostly didn't do shit. I was an emotionally unbalanced child who lashed out. Later on it became extreme reservedness and even dissociation in social events. No amount of going out to "desensitize" worked. Took me until last week to learn I was experiencing a sympathetic nervous system response. Last week. From YouTube, not the years with a therapist. But you know what? There are techniques to help manage a sympathetic nervous response, some I found online, but some with the therapist, and I've been using them, and they fucking work. It's miraclulous.

Try every cope before you try the rope. Maybe something'll work and revolutionize your life.

posts.name: Anonymous

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Now let's come back down to earth. Nothing you're talking about generates passive income.

Learning how to make games sounds great, but you have to be realistic that there's an awful lot of competition out there. You need much more than the ability to do basic pixel art and having read the unity documentation to make games people want to play, let alone games people will pay for or put up with ads to play.

There's a very good reason game design is a 4 year fulltime university course. I'm not saying you need to have the degree, you don't. I'm saying there's a plethora of diverse skill sets to learn, deploy and balance. Making games is easy. Making games not only that people want to play but that stand out amongst the crowd, that's really hard.

Please don't take me the wrong way, I'm not in any way trying to discourage you. What I am doing is trying to bring you back down to earth with realistic expectations for the future.

There is no such thing. Clinically, medically, physically, it is impossible to EVER become addicted to porn. Period. That you can sit here and say you're done looking at it, is just further evidence that it isn't an addiction and never has been. If this is a thing you've been having ongoing trouble with, it's something you should approach your doctor about to explore whether there are any physiological factors at play. Failing that, we're talking about psychological factors such as depression or performance anxiety.

Optional extended survey next post and then about me, if you want to give me advice directly.

Optional extended survey, skip if tl;dr

>How old are you, your spouse, and your kids now?
>How old were you when you had kids?
>How long have you been together?

>What do you and your spouse do for work?
>What are you paid hourly and how many hours a week?
>Did you have childcare support and how much? (family, daycare, etc)

>What kind of socialization did your kid have before starting school?

>How did you prepare to have kids, or how do you wish you prepared?
>What products were helpful, or you wish you bought?

>Did you always want kids or did you change your mind at some point?
>Do you have any particular regrets?
>What kind of conflicts have you had with your spouse and how has that changed over time?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
About me. Again, skip if tl;dr

I'm a 28 year old woman. My husband (36) and I have been together for 6 years, married for one. Before him I thought I never wanted kids because I was so lethargic, angry, and unreliable. Now, since then, I've gone through a lot of therapy, books, and support groups.

Something that seems insurmountable to me is the lack of support. We don't have really any family that can help and the cost of daycare/nanny is insane. This seemed extra horrifying when I was younger and had the belief that any husband would basically be useless.

But my husband likes kids a lot and is the one who wants kids. He's even has worked with disabled kids. I also realized that I had resigned myself to having two if any, thinking siblings were required for a well adjusted kid. I've now looked into only children and that seems more appealing.

Someone did ask me the other day, "If your husband didn't want kids, would you be sad about that?" I said that, at this moment, no, but I don't know if I'd end up sad decades from now. "Do you just want kids to appease him then?" Maybe. It's certainly a big factor.

I just don't know if it all comes down to my fears about decision-making and commitment. I have a lot of self-destructive avoidance in my life, is this just more of that?

I'm heading towards "geriatric" pregnancy and my husband has mused aloud about his age, calculating how old he'd be at a child's milestones. I've been open with him about my doubts and warned him that I may never be ready, and he's told me that's okay. But we're getting closer to the cut off where I need to tell him definitively one way or another.

There's just so much that can go wrong. I like my current quiet life, and kids are anything but. My mother's side of the family has history of both post partum depression and post partum psychosis. PPP confirmed in my mother's grandma, and I suspect in my mom. I don't know if I'll back slide in my mental health.

I'm just at a loss.

Still, no matter how tired I am, my daughters smile makes my face light up, and my husband would do anything for her even though she's still very small. The primal love parents feel for a child beats any mess the child has made.

>>28008008
Now, this is a very important decision. Assume you can support the child and be able to love them even if you had them by accident, issue is whether you want it or not. And it's a pretty huge commitment! I understand. I guess on one hand I haven't thought of it that way since my husband and I are the same age and still very much in our prime.
But, with only children, they turn out miserable. Siblings evoke either feelings of care and further empathy and serve as practice for caring for someone else in the greater world, they are known to share and keep each other busy. However only children don't compete for resources, so that leads them to be almost as expensive as 2+ kids and generally entitled to their privileges.
So, anonette, don't have an only child ever.
It's not worth the trouble later on, just have two if you already have one.
Also i think that you will likely regret it but seriously, have a chat with your husband. He may be musing about it but seriously talk about what you really want, make a plan, one kid, two, who you can support and when, etc.

We have no babysitter but reduced work hours for me and him as well, plus our mothers and fathers frequently help out since they want to.

Our daughter mainly socialized with her cousins, of which she has 3, all older than her (my husband is the youngest of the kids in his family), and we are generally very family oriented, our kid has a few close playground besties and neighbors as well. She does not go to school yet.

Preparation; well we didn't know we were going to have her. Namely, we had discussed it and made plans, just had not actively tried for a baby, just agreed we wouldn't try too hard and just go with the flow of life. We prepared as well as we could, opened a college fund already, also for private schools and stuff, looked into options, insurance and all that, how it would affect our life. The medical stuff was easy to deal with since my husband has a bunch of labor and delivery nurses to ask about random things if we have any questions about pregnancy and all that.

Products; probably extra thick pads, personally my pregnancy was easy. I say just continue working out and all that, the cushions are pure bs. Also Vaseline for stretching skin and chapped lips, omega 3, tretinoin cream for any blemishes (needs prescription). It's different for everyone.

Just enjoy it. Stop looking at what others have and just enjoy what you have.

FYI, there is no reason for you to be in poverty, unless you have some kind of learning disability.

You have several options available to you. Trade school, military, and College.

> Trade school
Not too familiar with this one, but I believe you can enter the Job Corps to receive training under a trade. You can also look up apprenticeships online for info about that.

> Military
You get great benefits from enlisting. VA loan, retirement plan, and having the military pay for your schooling (college).

> College
Since you're poor, the community college to university transfer is your best option. It's cheap. And if your family is genuinely poor, you qualify for FAFSA which means you basically go to college for free.

So, I'm going to pretend this isn't a larp. What I'm hearing when I read this post is

>> I live in a very small box and refuse to grow as a person. I'm not interested in anything outside of that box nor am I interested in people who enjoy things outside of said box.

At any rate to answer your questions

>> decent looking women that like anime in their 20s

These don't exist.

People normally grow and develop as they age. Their interests change, they seek out new things, they push against their comfort zone, they experience life and it causes them to periodically shift their perspective.

Anyone decent looking is undergoing this process and not hiding away from life like you're describing.

The other thing I'm hearing from your post is that any potential romantic interest from you has to go all the way to you, no diversity, no interests of their own, no compromise, no effort on your part.

That's of course not how relationships work. Functional relationships meet in the middle with compromise, mutual respect, variation in interests and equal effort. If you're unwilling to do these things you're completely wasting your time looking.

>>28006483
>People, and family in specific are not disposable things you can cast away at any moment.
I strongly agree, and something very similar is why I don't think he *should* treat you exactly like a son. If people are interchangeable regardless of what they are (sons, daughters, mothers, fathers, etc.), it's much easier to treat them as replaceable, too.

> whenever i outperform my brother in any accomplishment instead of being happy for me it's like if he thought something like "what a waste if only she was a male"
If I were a dad in a similar situation, I might be more concerned about my son because of the family name (and brooding over how to make him be less of a fuckup), but I'd be much more proud of my daughter. I wouldn't have the same expectations of them, though: for example, excelling at one's work or trade is relatively more important for men than for women.
Personal virtue is my top priority for both, but if my kids were to have some minor character flaws in exchange for extra ability (a bad trade most of the time regardless), it's a relatively worse trade in a daughter than in a son. Both men and women need to set good examples, obviously, but women have kids and most closely raise them, so they are typically the guardians of morality in the home. A man typically needs to provide a stable setting for that home. This isn't to say men and women can't or shouldn't help each other out and positively contribute to each other, but it does show the difference in priorities. A woman who becomes a worse mother so she can compete with a father isn't as praiseworthy as an excellent mother.

As the Dutch Calvinists put it, men and women are of equal moral worth, but they are not equal. Your father can and should love his daughter, but that love won't necessarily show in the same way as it would for a son. You should try to see whether your father loves and appreciates YOU rather than trying to 'beat' your brother.

(2/2)

First and foremost, there should be made a clear distinction between lolicon and pedophilia. Pedophilia is a form of paraphilia - an abnormal sexual desire, usually involving extreme or dangerous activities that can harm oneself or others. Pedophilia in particular is the sexual attraction of young, prepubescent children. Lolicon, on the other hand, is the sexual attraction to fictional characters, whether or not they are canonically prepubescent doesn’t matter as long as they appear to be so, which can be found in lolicon media in the forms of anime, manga, and other anime-related media such as visual novels. It’s also worth noting that pedophilia can be an attraction to both male and female children, whereas lolicon is exclusively an attraction to females. The male equivalent to lolicon is shotacon.

Now, why did I feel the need to define both words? That would be because some people confuse pedophilia for lolicon, and vise versa, and some use the words interchangeably. However, I believe lolicon to be a completely different sexual desire to pedophilia, and now I will try to explain why as best I can.

Pedophilia is a harmful sexual desire. Child molesters will try to groom and/or rape real, young, impressionable children. I cannot stress just how disgusted I am by child molesters, and I sincerely hope you’re disgusted - or at least angered - by them as well. There are also pedophiles who do not physically try to have sex with children, but still do directly harm them through child pornography. posts.sub: How can I be more superficial and fun?
posts.com:
I've been consumed by reading, thinking, and trying to find answers to politics, philosophy, religion, the meaning of life, etc., for the past few years. Now I'm done because I realized that I'm never going to find clean cut answers to those questions, so I found an answer that works for me and cut my losses. Unfortunately, I put almost all my other hobbies and interests on hold, and now I've become way too boring, serious, and unimaginative of a person (when I was already pretty serious to begin).

So, how can I be more superficial, light-hearted and fun? It seems like even something as simple as making jokes, looking forward to the next movie, playing a character, etc., has a lot of depth to it, even if it's all appearances. I know that practice makes perfect, but it's one of those things that I have no idea where to begin working on because it's so alien to me now. It's like I almost got rid of my entire personality for this quest.

posts.name: Anonymous

Don't refer to these people as superficial please.
You're not even that deep, everyone goes through the same shit, but manifests it in completely different ways.
It's just a phase of growing up, you'll need to adapt later in life, since I assume that you're pretty young. You don't need to fake anything, just get some friends and hang out with them, and learn that life isn't too serious.
Try to learn what's enjoyable and what's not, and how to enjoy it yourself, but there's no need to call the mundane things superficial, or feel superior to people who enjoy them. Just be open minded.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28007981
>>28009386
So there's a phenomenon called barometric pressure headaches, which are usually caused by a drop in pressure. ANC headphones don't change the pressure on your ears, but the lack of middle ear vibration tricks your body into thinking there is pressure.
Most of the time this actually causes people wearing noise-canceling headphones to get headaches, but if something is already wrong with your ability to regulate inner-ear pressure this lack of vibration might be actually giving you some relief.
This is just my hypothesis as a random guy on the internet, maybe book an appointment with an audiologist and check for any abnormalities.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28008510
You're nothing special, just a regular-ass "follower" human. Roughly 80-90% of the population are "followers": people who mostly sit around and consume, people who wait for others to take initiative for them. In friend groups, this is you.

The remaining 10-20% of people are some degree of "creator" or "leader" human: people who make things and take initiative and organize outings. Not all "creator" humans are the same, some are casual creators and others are hardcore creators. In friend groups, this is the guy who organizes shit, makes phone calls for reservations, checks everyone's coming and handles logistics, etc.

These groups aren't static and don't have hard borders, it's more of a rough categorization. Some "followers" aspire to more and ascend, some "creators" burn out and become followers, but there is a core to both groups that stays the same throughout their lives.

posts.com: How do I spend more time with people if my idea of "fun" is solitary in nature and i'm introverted? Besides being more open and looking for cues to invite myself to things I can't exactly start going "Hey stranger wanna watch tv together?". Or can I?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: In church it's pretty safe to ask people to hang out

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
99% of friendships are the result of spending time with other people in the same place, whether in class or work or similar activities. Open yourself up to casual conversation and let things develop organically. Learn to laugh at yourself and interpret people's intentions charitably. Don't overreact to teasing. Eventually you will have friendly acquaintances and also eventually some friends.

Also just because you "prefer" solitary activities doesn't make it impossible for you to socialize in low-intensity or one-on-one situations. Don't fall for the introvert vs extrovert meme. Obviously some people are more extroverted but you are not a special hypersensitive soul because you watch anime and stay in your room.

Switch to calisthenics then (Even then you'd need a pull up and dips bar but it's less than buying a gym's worth of equipment you'd need other vise).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
With dumbbells and a bench you can do a fair bit of upper body stuff:

-Pectoral flies
-Overhead tricep extension
-Front raises and side raises
-Urlacher curls
-Bicep curls
-Pullovers

Lower body is trickier, the only one I do with a bench and dumbbells is Bulgarian Split Squats, which are pretty difficult but effective.

posts.sub: Get over it
posts.com: How do it "get over it"?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
1) Take a self-analysis. What's really different? What's really changed?
2) Ask yourself, "What advice would I give to someone who's in the same or very similar circumstances?"
3) Find out what other people in your circumstances have done to get over it.
4) Talk about it with someone you trust. The more you put something into words, the less scary it feels. That's why people write about their trauma all their time.
